It makes sense IMO. Since you already created the test, can you also add the implementation? Just go for the simplest possible fix and make sure to keep unrelated changes like moving imports around to a minimum.

Also, please file an issue at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING so we can track the inclusion and your intention to contribute. Then the commit title should include that issue , e.g.

SLING-XYZ - Implement MockSlingHttpServletRequest.adaptTo(Resource.class)

Hi Robert,

please review: https://github.com/apache/sling/pull/85

Cheers!
Georg

Thanks for checking @kwin , I added the test I was trying to find!

Can be done with standard thymeleaf dialect:

``` html
<html data-th-with="page=${resource.adaptTo(@org.apache.sling.samples.fling.Page@class)}">
```

see: https://github.com/apache/sling/tree/trunk/samples/fling
Invalid, API doesn't work this way in Sling see SLING-4607.

Patch has been committed to sling - see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SLING-4665?focusedCommentId=14518971&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-14518971

It would be great to have a SLING jira issue opened to discuss this enhancement, including how to reproduce the problem :-)

Ah, so there is SLING-4813 ... please include the issue id in the commit title to make sure the links are created.

Can you also include a minimal unit test 'proving' that the problem is solved?
yes, I have no time for it. I try to do it soon, but currently have to meet some deadline...
done
Thanks for the PR @visiongeist ! Some unit tests to go with this would be great. There are examples for this in the module but it those aren't clear enough let me know

@tiennv90  - thanks for the pull request! Overall it looks good, but I think the code could be revised to have less duplication. For instance, `testErrorLogger`, `testWarningLogger` and `testInfoLogger` are mostly the same. I also think `testBundleChanges`, `testFrameworkEventStarted` and `testFrameworkEventError` can be refactored.

Once the duplications are removed I will be happy to merge this pull request.

Hi @rombert 

I removed the duplications as your comment, please recheck the pull request.

Thanks for the submission, overall it looks good. A couple of notes:
- can you please add a sanity check which ensures that we don's select two conflicting options? `sling.useSlingPost` and `sling.usePut` can't both be true. And come to think of it, perhaps we should add a String parameter which describes the method used, e.g. `sling.deploy.method` which initially takes the values `webdav,webconsole,postServlet`
- would it make sense to extract the if/else statements into an interface with three implementations, as outlined above ( that would also make writing tests in the future much easier )

Sure a sanity check could be added to raise an error if both usePut and useSlingPost are both true. I was thinking about adding this, but wasn't sure if it was expected/appropriate.

As for adding a new deploy method, this would add some simplicity going forward for clarity purposes, but is it expected that this is an additional parameter and usePut still exists for backwards compatibility purposes so we would need to support both ways of setting, or would it be expected that usePut is removed, breaking backwards compatibility?

> Sure a sanity check could be added to raise an error if both usePut and useSlingPost are both true. I was thinking about adding this, but wasn't sure if it was expected/appropriate.

I think it's better to fail hard. For instance if usePut is set to true in a parent pom and useSlingPost locally, it can get quite confusion.

> is it expected that this is an additional parameter and usePut still exists for backwards compatibility purposes

My suggestion would be to always obey the new parameter if non-null, and fall back to checking `usePut` if needed.

> I think it's better to fail hard. For instance if usePut is set to true in a parent pom and useSlingPost locally, it can get quite confusion.
> My suggestion would be to always obey the new parameter if non-null, and fall back to checking usePut if needed.

So instead of adding the `useSlingPost` boolean option, add the more flexible (future friendly) `sling.deploy.method` String option, which is allowed to be not specified.
So this seems to logically break down to 
- If `sling.deploy.method` is specified use that as specified (error out if invalid)
- if `sling.deploy.method` is not specified, check for `usePut` (backwards compatibility).
  - `usePut` is true -> use WebDAV
  - `usePut` is false -> use Felix Webconsole.

Or am I missing something here?
Looks good to me

Added an additional commit here for switching from the `useSlingPost` boolean parameter to the `sling.deploy.method` String type parameter.
Let me know if the two commits should be squashed for convenience.

I agree that it would be likely better in the long term to switch things around to declare an interface for the deployment strategy and have different implementations, but given how invasive such a change would be, it warrants more discussion/collaborated thought on coming to a desired design strategy.

Actually question I have here now is, is the documentation at http://sling.apache.org/site/sling.html automatically generated from the Mojo, or is there somewhere that manual updates should be made for this change?
Applied, thanks for the contribution!

@cziegeler  fyi, Documentation.

Thanks a lot for the pull request @schaefa !

Looking at the changes I see that these new classes are not integrated at all in the project. To make it possible to test and for me to understand how they fit in I would like to ask you to actually 'plug in' these classes where they are needed in the current project.

I cannot do that as I don't have the time to get up to speed, the knowledge and also not the access to the source code in question.

That said I did a pseudo implementation (based on my Eclipse wrappers) inside the AEM Tooling Plugin for IntelliJ (https://github.com/headwirecom/aem-ide-tooling-4-intellij/tree/develop/src/main/java/com/headwire/aem/tooling/intellij/io/eclipse). This should give you a hint on how I envisioned the implementation inside Eclipse. It is for sure not perfect as I cut corners in my wrappers.
I see. So this is rather a proposal on how the APIs can evolve and a starting point for a discussion? And not used in the IntelliJ part either?

No, this isn't a proposal and it is used in IntelliJ. The parent folder of the one I mentioned contains the IntelliJ code. The eclipse folder is a proposal on how Eclipse could implement the API (SlingResource etc).
